channel.title: Should Produk continue to make future bass?
channel.description:
Idk, I feel like I've bled this genre dry and there's too much competition these days. I can't make anything that I like and that sounds original at the same time. Most of my songs have been recycled ideas or re-skinned fan-favorites. I just don't feel the vibes anymore. But then again, I've gained over 200 followers 25K plays from big hits like Singularity. I've made a name for myself in the future bass area(I think lol) and IDK if that's worth switching around to another genre or not. Then it comes down to "Do I want to have a trademark sound or should I throw any brand I may have developed in the future bass world in the trash?" Should I move on or should I stay?
[poll type=regular public=true] * Keep producing future bass. * Move on. [/poll]

item.title: Should Produk continue to make future bass?
item.dc:creator: tornait
item.description:
Whoa, there mate. That last bit struck a nerve with me. Well, what if some people use remix contests to get their names out there? Besides, everyone should look at that type of stuff as a challenge. I really do hope you’re being sarcastic, as there’s a lot of new people coming through who are being kept at the bottom instead of being allowed space to grow.

item.source: Should Produk continue to make future bass?

item.title: Should Produk continue to make future bass?
item.dc:creator: calmor
item.description:
You know what I think you should do?

Do you.

Make music you enjoy. Make whatever you believe sounds good to you. Like others have said, your followers followed you, for you. WE follow you for you. For everything you make. Switch things up, or keep doing what you’re really good at. Nothing wrong with either of those.

As music enthusiasts and producers, evolving our own sound, trying new things, or staying within a genre we’re comfortable in is what it’s all about. Because it’s based on ourselves, and our interests.

Hope this helps you somehow <3

Read full topic

item.source: Should Produk continue to make future bass?

item.title: Should Produk continue to make future bass?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Produk:

I actually really like this idea.

It’ll be a secret tho.

While it’s worth keeping projects separate (so as not to dirty up your output for the purists in your existing audience), I’m not sure there’s value in keeping other projects secret – unless you really think that one project is likely to harm or undermine the other.

Otherwise, there might be value in (heavily) cross-promoting the two projects by linking between the two on SC/social channels. You might find that the followers/listeners that you’ve already built up are happy to engage with other projects you’re working on – which is better than building up a new audience from scratch.

Read full topic
item.source: Should Produk continue to make future bass?

item.title: Should Produk continue to make future bass?
item.dc:creator: Ninjendo
item.description:
For me, I started as an experimental artist which still remains today. I experiment with different sounds and format them in different styles. I think that you can keep your name just make sure that you don’t radically change your style to the point that your listeners don’t feel S H O O K.

item.source: Should Produk continue to make future bass?

item.title: Should Produk continue to make future bass?
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
akabillposters:

If you’re going to switch genres entirely (as opposed to opening up and evolving your sound), maybe consider releasing the new music under a different name.

This – Actually, icsleepers is a side project for just Auxy stuff. My main stuff is under a different name. I’ve had AT LEAST five different named projects over the last… 18 years or so?

On the topic of our friend Richard D James:

Aphex Twin
AFX
Polygon Window
Blue Calx
Caustic Window
Power-Pill

and on and on and on. The guy has more pseudonyms than I have teeth I’d bet.

Read full topic
item.source: Should Produk continue to make future bass?

item.title: Should Produk continue to make future bass?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
If you’re going to switch genres entirely (as opposed to opening up and evolving your sound), maybe consider releasing the new music under a different name.

It allows you experiment and play around with other styles without undermining whatever ‘purist’ following you’ve built up under the FB name.

It doesn’t have to be a secret, but it’s possibly ‘cleaner’ and possibly even more fun that way.
(Have you heard any of the super-cheesy raven-techno that Aphex Twin produced under a different name, or the harder, more esoteric stuff under the AFX name?)

(It’s quite common in electronic music to have side-projects producing different styles under different names.)

Read full topic
item.source: Should Produk continue to make future bass?
